cab.content: (T:;IS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT.)idSECRET.WAR CABINET 428A.DRAFT MINUTES of a Meeting held at 10 Downing St.,S.W.,on FRIDAY, June 7,19l8, at 11-30 a.m.LETTER FROMGENERAL FOCHTO FIELD-MARSHAL SIRDOUGLAS HAIG.The Director of Military Intelligence read to theWar Cabinet extracts from a letter he had received fromGeneral DuCane, in which the latter stated that he had, onthe previous day, taken a letter from General Foch to theBritish Commander-in-Chief asking him, in view of theimminence of an attack on the Montdidier-Noyon front, tomake the necessary preparations to come to the assistanceof the French with all his available reserves. GeneralFoch had also charged General DuCane to explain to theCommander-in-Chief that he had no intention of acting soimprudently as to withdraw reserves from the British zoneuntil it was quite clear that the bulk of Prince Rupprechtbreserves were committed to action South of the Somme.General Foch also said that he had not asked for more thanfive Divisions of Americans to go into the French zone.General DuCane had stated that General Petain had askedthat as many divisions as possible of the IXth Corpsshould be reconstituted in the French zone.The Prime Minister said that he had talked to theChief of the Imperial General Staff on the telephoneyesterday evening, who had said that he had no knowledgeof this information.BRITISH ANDFRENCH DIVI-SIONS IN LINE.The Director of Military Intelligence stated thatthe number of British and French Divisions on the battle-front, i,e. from Montdidier to Rheims, leas the Illrd Army,was ae follows In line........ 26Withdrawn ...... 13Reserves in"battle area ... 7Arriving ....... 1The French Divisions on the Illrd Army front were asfollows :-In line ........ 9In reserve ..... 4Arriving ....... 3* /The opinion was expressed that the aboveinformation appeared to be quite satisfactory.2 Whitehall Gardens, S.W.,8th June, 1918.
